climbs.name: Y- Left (submitted as Why Left)
climbs.fa: Mark Tjaden , C.J. Sidebottom, & Brian Shelton

content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is just right of

Doggie Style

.

content.description: This is a bolted crack with good hand/fist jamming, left of Sky, Blue Sky and Shredulator.
content.location: Scramble up to a ledge to belay.  It is left of Sky, Blue Sky and Shredulator.

content.description: Named after the Apache god, this has slightly techy climbing following pockets, edges, cracks, and weaknesses. The hardest part seemed to be getting to the first bolt.
content.location:
It is the 3 bolt climb just to the right of

Number 1 Super Guy

.

content.description: This face climb works left, then back right and then up to the anchors.  The crux between the 6th and 7th bolt can be avoided by climbing to the left and then traversing right to clip the last bolt.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a ledge with high anchors above.
content.location:
This route is on the Piggy Bank Wall between

Pinon Slalom

and

Ladies Night In Buffalo

.

content.description:
This is the second bolted line to the right of

Number 1 Super Guy

. This route provides some face, arete, and mantel climbing. The climbing isn't that outstanding but allows great positioning for photos of leaders on

Number 1 Super Guy

. It would make for a great, easy/moderate warm-up.
This climb has sustained 5.7 moves up the face. Storm the Castle!
content.location:
This is about 30 feet the left of

Buns

, around the corner.

content.description: This route is listed as B&C in the new guidebook.  Start in the middle of the face, behind the large pine tree.  Work up the face and the right crack of a double crack system.  While this line has a lot of face climbing, it also yields quite a lot of crack technique and several nice ledges for resting.  Continue working the crack until it runs out on a ledge.  Work up a right-facing dihedral to gain a large anchor ledge.  Rappel to descend.
content.location:
This route is on the face right of

Shady Character

.

content.description: Climb a slabby face right of a large, right-facing crack.
content.location:
This is the second route right of

Flesh Tuxedo

.

content.description: This fun, new route starts in a shallow, left-facing dihedral and eventually meanders up and right to anchors below a roof.  There may be no definitive crux move, but the top becomes a little steeper as you shoot for the chains.
content.location:
When approaching from the Piggy bank trail, take a left at the fork.  This route sits on the first buttress, just to the right of

Crab Nation

.

content.description: Start below a shallow corner, staying either to the right on the face or use the large, scary flake on the left.  Juggy pockets lead to a good stance followed by a thin and technical face.
content.location:
This is the leftmost route on the first buttress to the left of

Flesh Tuxedo

.

content.description:
Start just right of the bolted crack "

Who Asked You?

". Some moderate moves leads to a roof where the cranking begins. A thin crack shoots up from the roof, think fast and look around for the non-obvious moves through this section.
content.location:
This is located about 200-300 feet to the left of

Number 1 Super Guy

on a white panel of rock.

content.description:
Start with face/crack moves to C1. Move up and left to gain C2. Continue up on good fingery pockets through a left trending section to a great stance at C4.

Go up past good vertical holds bearing right through C5 and C7 to another no hands. Climb straight up on great crack and face moves to the reachy anchors.
content.location:
At

Piggy Bank

, it is in between

Heaven is Waiting

&

Large Marge

.

content.description: Start out a small roof and go to a steep face.
content.protection:
5 bolts to shared anchor with "

Bridget the Midget

."
content.location:
This is just left of "

The Ginger Midget

" at the far left Piggy Bank area.

content.description: Shelf Life is a super vertical route with lots of pockets and ledges. The crux requires a few high steps near the middle section.
content.protection: You can climb this route with a standard rack, but it will hold pro up to #5. There are bolted anchors up top with rap rings.
content.location:
This trad route is the third route to the right of

Number 1 Super Guy

and is the first route to the left of

Season Down Under

. Start in a left-facing corner.

content.description: Start just left of a prow and ramble up easy holds on what looks like dark brown, petrified mud to reach the first bolt.  Traverse right to the arête and continue up on rock thats a lot more solid than it looks.  At the third bolt, cross over to the left and up, traversing past the 4th (crux) and 5th bolts.  From there, fire up the left side of the bolt line utilizing the large flake to gain the anchor.  Rappel to descend.
content.location:
This route is to the left of

Alcohollica

and two routes to the right of

Number 1 Super Guy

.

content.description:
This [was] rarely climbed, probably due to its mixed nature. Natural gear [was] required along the top crack.

Eds. Per

Aaron Glasenapp

: this route has gone through a few phases. It was first climbed on gear sans bolts, certainly the boldest style considering the sparse placements on a limestone face climb. 4 bolts were later added making this a largely ignored, still runout mixed route with some not-so-great fall potential.

It is now fully bolted with new stainless glue-ins, has a couple of engaging cruxes (11a) and a nice 10 foot crack for good measure. At the top of the crack, you have the option to trend right and finish on the last 2 bolts of

Gen X ation

, or trend left and finish on the last bolt of

Starving Hippies

.

Puking Yuppies makes a good companion to the popular

Gen X ation

and a good precursor to the more sustained

Starving Hippies

. Climbing all 3 of these routes in a day makes a good session of 5.11 sport climbing.
content.protection:
Originally: 4 bolts and gear (1/2 to 1 inch) to the anchors.

Eds. Now it is 9 or 10 bolts, depending on how you finish, plus 2 quickdraws for the anchor. 4 bolts were added to this route with permission from the FA (Richard Aschert) and approval from the Pike's Peak Climbers Alliance. Therefore, this route no longer merits a PG-13 rating.
content.location:
It is the middle route on the buttress to the left of

Flesh Tuxedo

.

content.description: This crack has been nicely bolted.
content.location:
This is the obvious bolted crack to the right of

Pinon Slalom

on the Piggy Bank Wall.

climbs.name: Project Focus
climbs.fa: Mark Tjaden, CJ Sidebottom, Rob Masters, and Brian Shelton

content.description: Pull over the bulge, and alternate between jamming and smearing up the dark face.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This route lies on a dark panel of rock around the corner from

Crab Nation

.  It sees shade most of the day and is better saved for warm days.

content.description: This route runs up a right-facing corner with a nice finger crack the whole length and decent feet except in the mid-section. This is the crux. The feet require some smearing for a few moves, but you can stem at the same time and hang on some great hands.
content.protection: A standard rack and nuts. Anchor to the big pine tree on top of the cliff, and rap off in whatever direction you feel is safe.
content.location: The route is located about 25 feet to the right of "Who Asked You" in an obvious corner.

content.description: Pull the roof after the mid-anchor (Mussies).
content.protection: There are an additional 2-3 bolts for the route + 2 for the anchor, unless you're cleaning.
content.location: Extension pitch above Pink Torpedo. An additional 2-3 more draws. Upper anchor is equipped with Mussies as well.

content.description: Follow the line of weakness up right and then left, passing a very suspicious and hollow sounding block below the anchors.
content.location:
This route is located on the Piggy Bank Buttress that includes

Crab Nation

. The buttress has a shady, right-facing dihedral on its far right side.  This route lies just to the right of that dihedral.

content.description:
P1. The start is overhung but juggy through some really neat rock.  It is a lot different than most of the stuff at Shelf.  After passing the pink rock, continue up the vertical face with small ledges.

P2. You can continue after the anchors past 2 more bolts to another set of anchors (5.11).  The crux is down low, but it doesn't let up much after that.

This is a very fun route!
content.protection:
Five bolts (6?) to the first set of anchors.

Pitch 2: ?
content.location:
This route is on the Piggy Bank Wall.  SLIM is to the right and

Flesh Tuxedo

is to the left.

content.description: Like the name suggests, climb up and between some small pinon pine trees.  There is an obvious crux up high.
content.location:
This route is between

B&C

and

The Brothel

.

content.description: Start with some broken rock to gain the wide crack en-route to clip 1. Cruise the thinner crack with good holds for 2 more clips to a stance as the thin crack peters out.  Move up the continuing steeper crack with face holds and jams for 5 more clips to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank

, this is just right of

Gen X ation (aka Musso Route)

.

content.description:
Climb the obvious dihedral between two bolted faces (currently labeled "

Project Focus

" and "

Poncho

"). It's a bit of a one-move wonder. The crux is pulling the roof about 20 feet up using either hand jams or a lieback. After that, it eases up a bit. There's an easy offwidth move toward the top.

It's a bit dirty, but the loose rock I found was pretty minimal (small and not too hazardous).
content.protection: Single rack to 4". Build off natural pro and walk off down the gully to the right.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the left Piggy Bank Wall.

content.description:
This is a bolted route between

Unknown 5.7

and

Bum Cakes

(Buns). It is a pleasant sport route along an arete with a crack for a part of the climb. It's easier if you climb left of the arete (less steep, with lots of holds) and more difficult if yo climb to the right of the arete (steeper, fewer big holds).
content.location:
This unknown bolted route is between

Unknown 5.7

and

Bum Cakes

(Buns).

climbs.name: Old But Not Dead
climbs.fa: Staci Suter, Bob Robertson, & Reggie Slavens

content.description:
Clip the first two bolts of

Large Marge

, then continue up the arête for eight more bolts. The route has it all: steep crack to technical face climbing on top. The anchors are six feet left of

Large Marge's

anchors, making it a great toprope.
content.location:
This is just left of

Large Marge

.

climbs.name: Number 1 Super Guy
climbs.fa: Kevin Gonzales, Dave Dangle, Eric Harp, 1988

content.description:
What an amazing roof!  This has the potential to be a complete sandbag at 11a, you are forewarned!

For the roof lover - the only reason the climb isn't 3 stars is the loose start.  Climb a easy, slightly loose, stemming dihedral with a piece of pro or two to a ledge.  Climb the balancy, fun face to beneath the roof.  Clip the bolt behind you on the roof.  Sandbagged with bad beta, I climbed this the hard way with the most tremendous reach I've ever made.  There is an easier way, but I'll let you puzzle this one out yourself.
content.protection: 5 bolts? or so to 2 bolt anchor.  A couple medium nuts will protect the start.
content.location:
It is difficult to find.  It is in the north end of the north wall of the Bank. Between Quarry Wall (

Dust Lust

,

A Sharp

) and #1 Super Guy, there are low cliffs with few lines then a gully. The next cliff band has #1 Super Guy on the far left side climbing the prominent roof, but the approach is from the road up to the right side of this wall (several routes here:

Starving Hippies

, 11b/c;

Incredible Weather

, 12c/d; and

Flesh Tuxedo

, 11b, among others) then hike left along the cliff to find the line.

climbs.name: Lloyd
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton, Mark Tjaden, and Stewart Green

content.description:
This route has short, moderate, crack and face climbing with some sharp holds on the top half. It doesn't look like this has seen much traffic yet.

There is a directional bolt at the top that can be used from

Harry's

anchors.
content.location:
It is one route left of

Harry

(2 routes left of

#1 Super Guy

, right around the corner).

content.description: Start climbing the sharp slabby rock that goes vertical towards the top. There are a few good hand jams and lots of finger cracks. Stem the right-facing corner to get to the bolted anchors.
content.protection: A standard rack with bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: This ascends a right-facing corner located in between The Brothel and Pinyon Slalom.

content.description: This is a new bolted route that may follow a previously trad line up under a roof, into a large offwidth/chimney, then up a finger crack to anchors.  There are good jugs down low to the roof, the offwidth actually provides a good rest -- the crux is the finger crack at the top before the anchors.
content.protection: This was newly bolted by someone, with nice spacing and protection on lead.  There are about 9 bolts to two bolt anchors.
content.location:
The route is between

Generation X

and

Heaven is Waiting

.  The wide crack above the small roof makes it easy to find.  (See the photo of Mike on lead.)

content.description:
Start just left of the small corner and grab great holds to clip C1. After clipping C1, move to the corner with tricky feet, and then really reachy pockets to clip C2.

There is a small rest out right with a great right hand rail.

Continue on with sharp, vertical rock to a reachy C3. Once past C4, some easier ground gets you to one more clip and the chained anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

this is just left of

Crab Nation

.

content.description: This is a new route on the Piggy Bank Wall and is still very dirty.  Nonetheless, it is a great climb that requires at least some crack jamming skills to finish.  It starts at a lower angle for the first couple of clips and then steepens up into a crack where you can use a combo of crack and face moves with a finish that requires your hand and feet in the crack and goes to the anchors.
content.location:
This is right of

Pig City Nights

, left of

2010A

, and 2 routes left of

jasonbecker.com

on the Piggy Bank Wall.

content.description:
Start in the corner with great holds everywhere through 2 clips to a ledge at C3. At C3, start moving up and right into the corner. Gain C4 and move past Large Marge on great jams & face holds past C5 to C6.

Move up and left on great hands with some tricky feet through C9 to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

start several feet left of

Starving Hippies

.

content.description: This climb starts with a couple of cracks and a large flake to the right.  After the cracks, clip some bolts while climbing over some blocks.  Then the fun starts.  Climb up a steep face clipping a couple bolts and gain the anchor.
content.location:
The route is right in between

The Brothel

and

Heretic

on the Piggy Bank Wall.

content.description:
Start with some stemming and face holds to get to clip 1.

Move to the face for some sustained climbing for 3 clips to a reachy hold under the bulge.  Lieback the bulge moving left with killer fingers for 2 clips to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

start left of

Incredible Weather

.

content.description:
Ascend the *very* thin, white face 15 feet to the right of

jasonbecker.com

.
content.location:
Hike to the bottom of the bank road, looking for a cairn and trail up to the right.  The trail leads to the far north Bank routes splitting at the top between the Bank Rob and Piggy Bank Walls.  Take a left, aiming around the corner of

Flesh Tuxedo

.

content.description: Great holds to a stance. Go left for the good holds over the small bulge to another stance up and past C2. Vertical climbing on good holds to great pockets gets you to another stance by the small block on the left. Skirt the block to the right with good crimpy holds, and then head up & left past the block to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

this is in between

Alcohollica

&

Ladies Night in Buffalo

.

content.description: Climb great vertical/sharp holds to a small stance @ C2 with nice rest jams.  Go right with juggy holds over the small bulge/roof to another small stance right of C3.  Sustained, vertical climbing on good edges and nice pockets through 4 clips gets you to the anchors.
content.location:
At

Piggy Bank

, it is in between

Lick & a Promise

&

Stranger in Moscow

.

climbs.name: Harry
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton, Mark Tjaden, and Stewart Green

content.description: This is a short, 3 bolt route with easier climbing down low. The crux seemed to be getting to the anchors.
content.location:
This is just around the corner to the left of

#1 Super Guy

.

content.description:
Start as for

Y- Left (submitted as Why Left)

up blocky terrain to the high first bolt. After the first bolt, head right using some shared holds with

Y- Left (submitted as Why Left)

initially. Use pockets and sidepulls aiming for the bolted crack higher up. I stepped across the wide crack mid-route while laybacking the edge of the wide crack up to the finger crack. This was fun.

Finish using finger locks in the upper crack and sharp holds near the anchor. Nice position.

This route is called "Generation X" in

D'Antonio's new Shelf Road book.

It is not to be confused with the much easier and more aesthetic

Gen X ation (aka Musso Route)
content.protection: 8 bolts (?) to a two-bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location:
The route climbs the face right of

Y- Left (submitted as Why Left)

.

content.description: This has sustained face climbing to gain the arete.
content.protection: 11 clips to anchors with Mussy hooks.
content.location:
This climb is on the Piggy Bank Wall right between

Puking Yuppies

and

Pig City Nights

.

content.description:
Getting to this climb requires a pretty involved scramble up to an exposed ledge. The first bolt is easy to clip from the ledge. The climbing is fun, technical, and exciting.

Beware of a bit of loose rock.
content.location:
It is around the corner from

Number 1 Super Guy

to the west.

content.description: Start on a black face just left of a scary-looking, detached pillar and work up left of the bolt line, following a crack.  As the crack runs out and turns into a small roof, work up and right.  The crux comes at the fourth bolt, a delicate move up the face, avoiding the pillar.  Using the pillar downgrades the route by a half grade.    Continue up the bolt line on easier ground to a two bolt anchor.  Rappel to descend.
content.location:
Gambino is the line of bolts just left of the detached pillar and 20 right of

The Sweepings

.

content.description: This climb ascends good holds up the steep red rock leads to a casual face section on big holds. Shake out before the final crux. There are long reaches through the final crux either with low feet for the taller climbers, or higher feet for the vertically challenged. It is not as sandy as the guidebook suggests. In my opinion, this is the best route on the Northern-most end of the Bank North.
content.location:
This route is located on the Northwest side of the Bank North about 300 feet right of

#1 Super Guy

. The obvious, steep, red face right of an arete with a clean, white, middle section to a small overhang near the end.

content.description: Start with blocky rock to gain C1. Continue on some vertical climbing with great holds to C2. As the angle of climbing increases, stay in the corner with good but some hidden reachly holds.  Follow the crack system with good holds and then bear left at C7 and then back right at C8 to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

this is in between

Abu Simbel

&

Why Left

.

content.description: This is an interesting trad route. There are lots of loose rocks that need to be cleaned.
content.protection: Bring a rack with plenty of small nuts and cams.
content.location:
This lies about 30m east of

Number 1 Super Guy

.

content.description:
Start on

Incredible Weather

, and move straight up vertical, sustained climbing to clip C1 on the right. Go to reachy jugs at C2, and continue on great, vertical holds past C3 through C5 to a great, no hands rest up and right. Move up and left to pull the crux bulge straight on with smooth holds or step left at C5  with strenuous hands and tricky hard feet with more reachy / good holds to another rest on top of a small boulder sticking out of the wall.

Sustained climbing through 3 more clips will get you to the anchors.
content.location:
At

Piggy Bank

, it is in between

Incredible Weather

&

Flesh Tuxedo

.

climbs.name: Dirty Deed
climbs.fa: Reggie Slavens and Carrie Robertson,  29 Feb. 2012

content.description: Climb the black, west-facing pillar. Look for a low first bolt.
content.location:
It is to the left (west) of

Harry

,

Lloyd

, and Geek USA.

content.description: Grab good chalked holds to start and move straight up for 2 clips, then move left or right for a few clips to a rest. Climb up and through the short corner section. Gain the small roof passing 1 clip to the anchors.
content.location:
It is at

The Piggy Bank,

in between

Sty in the Sky & Misery

.

content.description: Follow a crack on the right to the roof.  Enjoy the hand jam in the left crack and gain the roof.
content.location:
This is approximately 300 yards to the left of

Number 1 Super Guy

.

content.description: Bridget the Midget is a line just to the right of a corner. Climb steep face, move right to a right-facing corner to the top.
content.protection:
5 bolts to a shared anchor of "

Silver Rain

."
content.location:
Start just right of "

Buns/Bum Cakes

" and just left of "

Silver Rain

" at the far left end of the Piggy Bank area.

climbs.name: Birthing the Piggy
climbs.fa: Stewart M. Green & Brian Shelton, 2005 or 2006

content.description:
Climb the wide crack between

Pink Torpedo

and

The Sweepings

to the bolted anchor of

The Sweepings

for an optional belay. Then climb through the back of the squeeze chimney to the top and belay from a tree.

Descend by the gully to the right or carefully make your way to the anchors for

Poncho

(a short belay is recommended for reaching the exposed anchors).
content.protection:
Single rack to 3" plus #5 and #6 C4. You can skip the large gear if you use the first bolt from

The Sweepings

and/or run it out.
content.location:
At the Piggy Bank, right of

Pink Torpedo

, look for daylight at the top of the chimney.

content.description: This is a fun 5.7 with a variety of moves.  It is well protected with a lot of rests and is a good route for new sport climb leaders.
content.location:
SLIM is one of the first climbs on the Piggy Bank Wall.  It is just left of

Crab Nation

and just right of a detatched pillar.

content.description:
Start with  some low angled climbing for 3 clips. At C4 the terrain steepens and you can go left (arete & easier) or stay in the corner (.9+).  Climbing

left

offers great big side pully holds with tricky feet to a reach above C7 to a ledge and then 1 more clip to the anchors.

OR

stay

in the crack with sustained smooth jams and then aim for the same above ledge with 1 more clip to the anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

this is in between

Season Down Under

&

Heretic

.

content.description: Start on low angled rock to gain C1. Go with sustained vertical climbing on crimpers and pockets to C3.  At C3, move right to the big block undercling and go straight up on big holds with sustained climbing to and past C4.  Lunge to a big, reachy, flat hold with a killer, hidden locker behind it at C5.  Hang back then jet up and left to the hard to clip anchors.
content.location:
At

The Piggy Bank,

this is in between

Tuff Shed

&

The Don Show

.

content.description: The Ginger Midget has a steep start to a face.
content.location:
This is on the far left Piggy Bank area, past

Number 1 Super Guy

, a few routes right of "

Buns

."

content.description: The route starts lower angle through the first couple of clips and then steepens up.  A couple of clips before the anchors the route changes.  You lose all of your little ledges and crimpers and suddenly you have a couple of weird sidepulls on minimum feet to a right arm sloper. This is the crux.  Pull through it, and it eases up to the anchors.
content.location:
2 routes right of

Pig City Nights

, and just left of

Jasonbecker.com

.
